class_notes: (Prerequisites: Bio 141 or permission of instructor.) This is a course in human biology. It integrates content from evolutionary, biological, and social sciences to provide a foundation for understanding the processes that shape human beings across the life course. Specific topics include: principles of evolution and genetics relevant to the human life cycle, development and growth (in-utero through adulthood), reproductive processes (pregnancy, lactation, menopause), health and disease, plasticity and tradeoffs, aging and death. This course uses an evolutionary and comparative perspective, drawing on cross-cultural and cross-species examples throughout. We will focus on the biological systems (neurological, hormonal, and immune) that underlie behavior, reproduction, and health/disease, and discuss the influences of sociocultural and ecological dynamics on these systems. This course is a good option for students interested in health-related disciplines.
course_description: Human biology from conception to senescence, in an evolutionary and cross-cultural context, emphasizing neural and neuroendocrine processes underlying behavior and reproduction. Conception, fetal development, birth, infant growth, puberty, pregnancy, adult sexuality, and aging.
